Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Effects of warming induced increases in shrub abundance and changing seasonality on migratory songbirds in Alaskan arctic tundra.
Award.AbstractNarration: As a consequence of global warming, arctic North America has been ?greening? over the past several decades, with increases in relative abundance and size of shrubs documented in numerous locations. Much of the research on this topic examines how this shift toward more woody species affects element cycling, particularly carbon, with potential feedbacks to the atmosphere regionally and globally. To date, the response of higher trophic levels to such shifts in vegetation in the Arctic has not been well studied. One group that has been almost completely ignored is migratory songbirds; they have a complex relationship with shrubs that provide both shelter and food, both of which are directly affected by weather patterns. This research will characterize the interactions between tundra vegetation and migratory songbirds in habitats that differ in shrub dominance for five consecutive growing seasons that will differ in timing and severity of weather events. The team will 1) identify and characterize interactions between shrub dominance and weather to determine how these affect food and shelter availability for migratory songbirds; 2) examine how reproductive success of populations of two songbird species responds to variation in both shrub dominance and timing of spring snowmelt, and; 3) measure how both variation in shrub dominance and timing of spring snowmelt affect composition and size of the entire songbird community. The multi-year approach will allow for examination of how interannual variability in arctic seasonality, particularly the timing of snowmelt, impacts songbird communities. Because the increasing shrub dominance is occurring too slowly for organisms to respond to during the time period of a grant, the researchers will examine habitat usage in open tundra plots, moderate shrub dominance plots, and high shrub dominance plots, at each of four study sites on the North Slope of Alaska. These include Atigun Valley, one of the first tundra stops made by migratory songbirds as they travel north, and at Toolik Lake, farther north, including two additional sites farther north to increase the spatial scale of sampling. In five project years, they will sample intensively at all four field sites to investigate spatial and temporal variation in plant resources, arthropod abundance, songbird community composition, and the arrival, settlement and reproductive success of two songbird species. During five years they hope to capture a range of interannual variability in weather, onset of spring snowmelt, and biotic responses to provide and understanding of current relationships and to predict how future changes in climate and vegetation may affect these organisms. They also intend to verify the use of remote techniques for monitoring bird community attributes via bioacoustic recordings for conducting automated bird community censuses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Arctic is warming more rapidly and acutely than any other region, and the biological responses are proving acute. By studying two of the most common arctic-breeding long distance migratory species Lapland longspurs and Gambel’s White-crowned sparrows - our study contributes understanding of how songbird communities are likely to respond to warming-induced increases in woody shrub dominance, as well as the increasingly extreme and unpredictable nature of arctic spring conditions – both of which are predicted as global warming continues. To date, the main findings of our study are that: (1) the birds fine-tune the timing of breeding each year to match the highly dynamic nature of spring environmental conditions; (2) by 2050, we predict a northward shift in current Gambel’s White-crowned sparrow habitat range and an approximately 20 to 60 % increase in their preferred habitat extent, while Lapland longspur habitat extent will be reduced by approximately 20 to 60 %. Increasing shrub dominance is likely to be accompanied by a net enhancement in preferred arthropod prey availability; (3) while ecological characteristics at the territory scale are important to breeding habitat selection, while those in the immediate vicinity of nests are not. Further, although snowmelt patterns, canopy height, and ground surface wetness are the most important characteristics influencing songbird territory selection, variation in these characteristics among selected territories had no effect on reproductive success of the birds; (4) preliminary findings suggest that inter-annual variability in songbird reproductive success is primarily driven by spring environmental conditions which directly affect the birds, but also indirectly affect them through variability in food availability; (5) birds breeding at their northern range limit experienced a harsher environment with colder temperatures, but no differences in arthropod prey biomass between the northern limit and more southern sites were found. Males at the northern limit had higher body condition scores and higher stress hormone levels (prior to breeding) compared to individuals within the historic range, suggesting that “pioneering” individuals at the limits of their breeding range exhibit physiology and morphology that are distinct from individuals within the historic range; (6)  in years with colder and wetter conditions during the nestling period, reduced rates of nestling mass gain were observed in both species, and; (7) automated bioacoustic analysis of annual songbird community arrival dates were found to be highly correlated with traditional, field-based measures of the arrival dates for Lapland Longspurs, and to a lesser degree with Gambel’s White-crowned Sparrows, over our five year study period.  

In addition to these songbird specific findings, we found that: (1) a commonly used satellite sensor based measure of vegetation productivity (i.e. the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI)) may be capable of indirectly assessing how arctic consumers are responding to climate induced change in tundra vegetation; (2) greater woody shrub dominance increases tundra carbon uptake (via photosynthesis) not only due to greater leaf area, but also due to an extension of the period of maximum vegetation greenness, which extends the period of peak carbon uptake, and; (3) graminoid-dominated (i.e. grass and sedge dominated) tundra arthropod communities harbor significantly more large spiders and beetles than woody shrub dominated tundra, while the latter harbors greater fly and small spider biomass.
